comments.text:
Indeed it can be eaten. But be very careful, because the THC that is smoked 
and the THC that is ingested are quite different. If you decide to try it, 
make sure you wait at least 45 minutes after you eat a small amount before 
eating more. It takes quite a while to kick in, lasts much longer, and IMO, 
is much more intense.

comments.author: Dean Dubois

comments.text:
+Petr Jaroch

It's quite simple to understand.

When you take thc, it goes into the blood. From there it travels 
everywhere, brain included.

The brain have a treshold. when it's full it close the door. As soon as he 
is no full, he'll open the door. THC from the blood will be quietly waiting 
to get the open door for the brain.

During that waiting time, he'll travel throught the body and will 
eventually go to the kidney where it will be filtered and removed (to end 
in you bladder)

Smoking a lot will make you as high as you can be for as long as your 
kidney will take to filter all the thc from your blood (usually 8 to 16 
hours. in worse case after 24h all thc is removed.

I like to say it's like a glider. When you smoke you quickly reach cruise 
altitude. From that moment, the only thing your join will do is maintain 
you up there. You won't go higher but you won't get low until your body got 
rid of enough thc.


As for cookies, eat small pieces, every 10-15 min. so that you get a slow 
high that you can stop when you feel ok.

I'd say that someone who don't smoke everyday should'nt take more than 0.3g 
per 60g of cookies. and no more than 1g per hours.

I have to add that i tryed edible weed. I felt nothing and i thought it was 
a waste of good stuff so i rather simply smoke or vaporize. I understand 
the biology and how thc work but i have low poractical experiences.
comments.author: LordSignur

comments.text:
+LordSignur You're right but it's much more complicated to get the right 
amount of THC in a cookie than to say in a joint. A month ago, I made 
cannabutter out of my White Russian leafs and small buds and then baked 
some cookies. When I tried them, I figured out a whole cookie is too much 
if I don't want to be absolutely stoned for the next 10 hrs... My point is, 
it's best to use caution when trying edibles :)

All the rest is placebo effect and lack of experience.

LSD and Shrooms do to them is Salvia.  I smoked some 50x one time and 
goddamn.  I took a hit watching cartoons....then watched as the picture on 
the tv kind of "flowed" onto the floor.  Then I started freaking out, 
closed my eyes, then opened them and looked up at the ceiling and the 
picture on the tv was now on the ceiling.  Thankfully it ended about 3 
minutes later.  Having done LSD and Shrooms multiple times before that, I 
still was not prepared for an actual hallucination.  

I'm sure I will get "Well you didn't take good acid or shrooms then" but I 
can assure you, I did.  I had plenty of closed eye visuals on LSD of the 
type I "saw" on Salvia, but nothing has ever come close to that experience 
when it comes to open eye hallucinations.

comments.author: grahepo

comments.text:
+Felix T-Rex " Just because someone has a bad reaction to coffee, are you 
going to judge them as having something wrong with them?"
No, however, I would highly recommend against them engaging in use of 
cocaine, alcohol or marijuana (let alone ecstasy or hallucinogens) and - if 
their claims are that coffee caused them to experience psychological 
effects that lasted 2 years - I would suggest they seek psychiatric 
guidance to determine what the root cause might have been, as there's no 
possibility of coffee's active ingredients (which, like the active 
ingredient in marijuana, is metabolized quite quickly) causing such a long 
term effect, suggesting it was more to do with the individual's 
psychological state prior to use than the drug in question.

As for locking you up in a mental hospital, that is not what psychiatric 
guidance means - it means meeting with a trained professional to try and 
determine whether or not the effects you experienced may have more to do 
with some sort of psychological issues you are exemplary of, perhaps even 
some sort of neurological disorder which resulted in the prolonged and 
(comparatively) wildly-exacerbated effects you experienced.

There's nothing to be ashamed of in needing to get some help with 
psychological issues - thousands of people have them, and we'd be better 
off as a society if we abandoned the stigma associated with such issues and 
sought to assist those exhibiting them.
I'm not saying you're a looney mate, I'm saying there might in fact be 
something wrong with you - whether its a psychological disorder associated 
with your neurotic behavior or genuine physiological issues in your 
neurological systems - that could be helped through such guidance.

As for depersonalization disorder, initial investigation of the topic 
suggests this is not something marijuana would/could induce - certainly not 
for a period of several years - though it may temporarily exacerbate it in 
individuals already exhibiting or with a predisposition towards it.
Hence, the suggestion of seeking psychiatric guidance and the avoidance of 
other substances that might further/similarly exacerbate the condition.

As for my point, well, my point is that your claims as to what has befallen 
you through use of marijuana seems very uneven, your statements (like those 
of the journalist) don't quite make sense and heavily suggest someone 
trying to portray marijuana use as far more hazardous than is the reality, 
much like how marijuana has been portrayed in propaganda of the past (such 
as Reefer Madness) suggesting it could/did result in drastic and long-term 
alteration in psychological state and which was used as motivation to 
initiate the prohibition in the first place.
To use your own example, imagine if someone told you they tried coffee once 
and it resulted in horrific "depersonalization" effects lasting several 
years, then followed up that statement by saying they routinely snort 
line-after-line of cocaine, do ecstasy and psychedelic mushrooms, and 
further saying that "every time I try coffee its been a really unpleasant 
experience", thus suggesting they'd used coffee more than once despite 
those supposedly horrendous effects.
Doesn't quite add up, unless the person making the statement has some 
worrisome issues in terms of their judgment and/or general psychological 
state - if the effects were so horrific, so long lasting, why in the flying 
fuck would they try it more than once?
And, for that matter, why would they try - and continue to use - other 
substances with far more powerful effects, which could potentially further 
exacerbate their condition and/or result in similarly unpleasant, 
debilitating, long-lasting effects?
Answer: They wouldn't, unless they've got some issues they need to address 
that have nothing to do with the drug(s) in question.

I'll be the first to say marijuana - any recreational drug - is not 
necessarily going to have the same effect for everyone, and thus is not for 
everyone in that context, but I'll also be the first to call bullshit when 
I see someone making outrageous claims as to the effects of marijuana - 
such as that they resulted in multi-year psychological traumas from a 
single instance of exposure - or to call for psychiatric treatment if 
someone genuinely stands behind such claims.
comments.author: nilesrock024

comments.text:
+nilesrock024 thanks niles. I appreciate your concern (even though you do 
come across as a bit of an asshole in your last post).

I think you are very wrong in assuming certain drugs have exactly the same 
effects in everyone. If you google "depersonalisation marijuana" read up on 
a few experiences of other people. It may not have anything to do with you 
or your circle of friends, but realise there are a certain small percentage 
of people who get a really bad reaction. Just because someone has a bad 
reaction to coffee, are you going to judge them as having something wrong 
with them?

You are right that i should cease to take recreational drugs. Even though I 
have not had the negative effects of pot with even harder drugs. It does 
NOT mean that I am psychologically unstable - I am succesful in almost all 
facets of life. Maybe i have a fear of losing control more than other 
people. Does that  mean you should lock me up in a mental hospital?

So I still don't understand you point. Yes some people get really bad 
pychological reactions to it and should stop taking it (like the 
journalist). Is it not OK to say: weed is not perfect for everyone? I think 
thats what the author was trying to say.

I'm all for legalising weed, but i just want people to realise that weed 
ain't perfect. Like anything in life it has its upside and its downsides.
comments.author: Felix T-Rex

comments.text:
+Felix T-Rex You clearly did not read my comment in full, given the first 
line of your response is something I already addressed, so I will reiterate 
my sentiment and add further detail.

As for your (supposed) negative experience, allergy makes no sense, nor 
does 'ego death' - whatever the fuck that's even supposed to mean.
Marijuana's active compound was not present within your system after a few 
months, at most, after use, meaning that if you suffered with prolonged 
psychological symptoms it had nothing to do with the pot - it had to do 
with you and your psychological state.

Given marijuana is, without question or debate, one of the mildest mind 
altering substances available and you experienced a multi-year 
psychological effect - assuming that's not merely bullshit on your behalf - 
you are not in a safe psychological space to be undertaking further use of 
mind-altering substances, let alone more powerful examples of such 
substances.
To put it bluntly, if marijuana could cause that kind of effect on your 
psyche, there's no telling if/when you might suffer a significantly-more 
severe response to something like ecstasy (which is highly variable in 
chemical composition in the vast majority of its available forms) or 
hallucinogens (which have far greater capacity to cause severe and/or 
long-term psychological dysfunction).

If what you say about your experiences with marijuana is true - which, 
admittedly, I highly doubt, given you've used phrases such as 'every time 
I've taken pot' in conjuncture with claims of multi-year debilitating 
psychological response to even a single use (which, if true, suggests 
you've repeated usage after experiencing such an effect, painting you as 
even more psychologically unstable) -  then that you've not experienced 
anything negative thus far from things like ecstasy or psychedelics is 
almost certainly luck (or else your response to the marijuana was more a 
placebo effect resulting from dysfunction within your own mind than 
anything to do with the chemical effect of the plant), and - as a medically 
trained individual with extensive experience in the use of mind-altering 
recreational substances, and as someone who genuinely cares about your 
well-being and the well-being of those around you - I highly recommend you 
cease any and all use of mind-altering recreational drugs and seek 
professional psychiatric guidance (assuming you have not already).
Best of luck to you.
comments.author: nilesrock024

comments.text:
I think you mixed up shrooms/LSD with marijuana. A bad trip on marijuana is 
nothing that "messes with people's brains". It just gives you bad feelings, 
paranoia, anxiety, worst case scenario - panic attack, but it's only in 
your head, can be easily overcome, is temporary (5-15 minutes) and leaves 
no health problems whatsoever. It is very hard to get such a "bad trip" and 
it is nothing serious even, your first time of use should be under the 
supervision of an experienced user who can guide you and give you proper 
dosage. You are overexereggating the "terrifying experience" that a bad 
trip is.
comments.author: Rič

comments.text: I smell a troll
comments.author: MrWiibetrollin

comments.text:
+nilesrock024 different drugs affect different people differently. For me 
pot has a far more intensive effect on me than ecstasy. I can munch down 
ecstasy like there is tomorrow. Even shrooms i can take... provided I am in 
good company.

But every time i have taken pot, even with good company, it has been a 
dreadful experience. For some people pot is not for them... it doesn't mean 
they are crazy or whatever, it is just that they can't get in the groove 
with the drug. Call it an allergy if you will, or a psychedelic crisis even 
"ego death".
comments.author: Felix T-Rex

comments.text:
+Felix T-Rex Just gonna put this out there: if you're a neurotic type 
person, who has serious issues with 'losing control' such that it can 
trigger a panic attack of that measure and cause 'depersonalization 
disorder' for long periods of time, you probably shouldn't be engaging in 
recreational drug use of any sort - certainly not ecstasy. You're not in a 
safe psychological space to be engaging in such mentally taxing 
undertakings.

I have extensive experience with recreational drug-use and experimentation, 
am thoroughly familiar with the difference in effect substances can have 
upon differing individuals, and have been through and/or seen more than my 
fair share of bad trips, but such a severe psychological reaction - one 
exhibiting effects lasting more than a year - to one of the mildest 
recreational drugs available does not suggest you ought to experiment 
further with 'harder' drugs.
comments.author: nilesrock024

you just gotta know your drugs. Ecstasy on the other hand I am totally fine 
with, but me and pot just don't mix.

is weed. My point was you're acting like the only common effect

comments.author: b- dubz

comments.text:
+b- dubz Again; the term psychedelic or hallucinogen does not necessarily 
mean "hallucination". Psychedelic means mind opening, all psychedelic drugs 
open the mind to some extent or another. There are drugs out there that 
will make you hallucinate but aren't classed as psychedelics because they 
don't open the mind. 

Why do you think hippies used pot and LSD and shrooms together? Because 
they lead to a lot of the same hippie behaviors and ideas. Sure PCP will 
make you trip out like LSD but you don't see a whole lot of hippies 
lighting up PCP because even though it will make you trip it's not 
enlightening and it doesn't lead to the same path of psychedelic peaceful 
hippie living. It doesn't destroy your ego either and though marijuana 
doesn't destroy it either it can temporarily soften it. 

Point is cannabis is technically in it's own class but in the scientific 
community we technically have to group it in a class of drugs that already 
exists and that class is psychedelics/hallucinogens. It by far has most in 
common with them and again the term hallucinogen is very misleading because 
it doesn't necessarily mean hallucinations will occur. So in a sense I 
guess you could say the term 'hallucinogen' is propaganda therefore making 
that whole class propaganda but it is not suddenly propaganda just because 
weed shows up. Cannabis is a mild psychedelic case closed. It's not 
propaganda, there's nothing wrong with it in fact it's a very good thing 
and is one of the many reasons cannabis is so safe.

top_comment.text:
How come Cenk doesn't attack her on the veracity of her claims about the 
hospital stories and the stoned driver incidents in neighboring states.

I myself never have been an advocate of pot legalization and pretty much 
have been skeptical on those who have been selling as the solution for all 
of society's ills and the tax revenues. However, I am certainly willing to 
look at real proof regarding its impact on Colorado since this new law went 
into effect. So far all I have been able to see is a whole lot of anecdotal 
horror stories and no real evidence from those who have been asserting 
claims of the negative impact of the legalization.

If you have no real proof of something being bad, publishing obviously 
unsubstantiated accusations of its negative effects only serves to make 
your position look weaker not stronger.﻿
top_comment.author: channeIreview

comments.text: +channeIreview Fair enough.
comments.author: Dante Xavier

comments.text:
+Dante Xavier You obviously have not been reading much of what has been put 
out by the advocates of legalization. I am not denying the scientific 
evidence supporting both the medicinal efficacy or the potential benefits 
of the industrial usage of hemp. I am also aware that the whole "gate-way 
drug^ myth is entirely bogus as well as claims being made about addiction. 
However, I am not making things up when I suggest that the advocates of 
legalization have engaged in hyperbole. Nevertheless, the point of my 
comment was not to criticize their hyperbole but instead to point out that 
the unsubstantiated attacks by the opponents demonstrates the baselessness 
of the entirety of their claims.
comments.author: channeIreview

comments.text:
Oh I seem to have miss understood. I will say though that legalizing pot 
alone is not going to change things at this point. Problems were created by 
it that require serious change at the highest levels

comments.text:

thing, how can anyone argue against that.  The issue of contention is 
whether or not there's a correlation between the legalization of marijuana 
and the crime rate.  If your theory is correct, we should essentially see 
the same effects taking place in Washington State, which we aren't.

was cut in half.

comments.author: rauth666

comments.text:
+William Weaver Except for the fact that those statistics have already been 
discredited.  The crime rate had spiked significantly in 2013, specifically 
in May after weed had been legalized, with many assuming law enforcement 
had chosen to set a precedent that they would not let Denver descend into 
madness post legalization.  The crime rate in 2014 has reverted to baseline 
levels.  Also noting the fact that in 2013 Colorado passed new gun control 
laws that went into effect July 1st 2013.
comments.author: rauth666

comments.text:

comments.author: TheWiseZenShaman

comments.text:
+Deez Nuts That's complete and utter bullshit.  Prior to the legalization 
of marijuana the only people who could, and have, bought weed are those 
with connections.  You're also hypocritically, I might add, assuming that 
weed consumption has baselined, although we know for a fact that a new 
industry of weed tourism has arisen out of Colorado's legalization of 
marijuana, and it would be absurd to assume people that were already 
smoking marijuana would go out of there way to buy more expensive weed and 
fork over travel expenses to visit the state of Colorado.  Let's just 
emphasize the point that neither you or I are arguing against the 
legalization of cannabis.  We're arguing about the undesired consequences 
that will arise out of that said action.  You people are arguing that 
nothing bad is going to happen, even though as a matter of principal, all 
legislation has unintended consequences.
comments.author: rauth666

comments.text:
+rauth666 the biggest problem I have with your analysis  is that it assumes 
that prohibition has decreased consumption of cannabis...Which it clearly 
and demonstrably has NOT...Cannabis use is at an all time high. So the idea 
that more schizophrenics will be using cannabis because it is legal I find 
to be a baseless assumption...And as it stands, with such a huge number of 
Americans using cannabis there is virtually no evidence to suggest that 
cannabis causing moments of psychosis is a serious problem...
comments.author: Deez Nuts

comments.text:
+normtheclone You're making an absurd argument.  We aren't talking about 
abusing caffeine or other stimulants.  If someone's mentally ill any sort 
of stress factor can induce a psychosis.  We're talking specifically about 
alcohol and marijuana, both of which are used to specific desired effects. 
 The average person doesn't smoke weed and drink alcohol to simply admire 
the taste.  Both are equally as destructive on the mentally ill.  What 
we're talking  about is the unintended consequences of introducing 
marijuana, which up until this point wasn't as readily available to the 
average person as it is now.  Also, making the point that alcohol is a 
worse substance than weed isn't a valid argument, considering that your 
stance would essentially amount to adding to the problems associated with 
alcohol is some how a good idea.  Alcohol and it's destructive nature is a 
beast we have yet to figure out how to deal with.  We talk about all the 
victims of our drug laws, but we never talk about the sociological and 
economical problems associated with substance abuse.
comments.author: rauth666

comments.text: I'm not sure why anyone reads the NYT anyways.
comments.author: Karm A

comments.text:
i take heroin and other drugs all the times, but cant even smoke a lil bit 
of weed for the same reasons i get paranoid and anxious, it just isnt for 
me...  Im also very sensitive to coffee and can make me feel like i smoked 
crack in big doses.... All stimulants are very bad for me, i can only take 
opiates wich are expensive and addictive, my pot head friends think im a 
junkie, i say they are lucky they can tolerate pot...
comments.author: david maltais

comments.text:
+rauth666
Stimulants of all kinds, caffeine included, can induce psychotic symptoms 
and exacerbate such symptoms in people that already have them. In fact 
stimulant psychosis is a fairly common and well known phenomenon. Marijuana 
induced psychosis, on the other hand, hasn't even been confirmed and many 
studies have yielded conflicting results. In short, the available evidence 
suggests that caffeine is more likely to induce or exacerbate psychotic 
symptoms than marijuana. If you don't believe me, just search PubMed or the 
NCBI website.

Now regarding alcohol, your claims about its relative safety compared to 
marijuana are untenable. Alcohol doesn't just cause people to pass out, it 
can easily kill people and often results in severe BRAIN DAMAGE (its 
important to mention that brain damage, which is NEUROLOGICAL is much worse 
that psychosis which is PSYCHOLOGICAL). Alcohol in fact has a therapeutic 
index slightly higher than that of opiates and comparable to that of 
cocaine, meaning that it is extremely easy to overdose on. It also impairs 
coordination and thinking much more than marijuana, which is evident if you 
consider either how it works in the brain or the fact most violent crimes 
and many car accidents involve the use of alcohol.
comments.author: Bleach Drinker

comments.text:
+rauth666 yeah you can only smoke so much pot before you fall asleep. you 
wake up happy and refreshed as opposed to hung over and sick.
comments.author: Adam Hickam

comments.text:
+rauth666 people don't have guides to use cannabis properly. Shamans are 
medicine men that do just that. Rather than doctors who tell you to take a 
drug, or a pharmacist who gives you the drug. In our pharma based society 
we have three bodies telling us about drugs. Doctors, pharmacists, and 
corporations. They all sort of tell you what a drug does, and what to 
expect, as well as what you should do but they don't guide you. 

No one guides you through getting drunk. 

But we have guides for driving cars. Guides for spending money. Guides for 
going places. All of the guides we have are for things we do outside the 
body. None for within 

Shamans are necessary for us to truly understand and be able to handle the 
journey drugs take us on. as more and more people try these things we will 
need people to help understand them, rather than "you're going to feel 
floaty." "you feel floaty because thc is broken down inside your body, blah 
blah blah. "
comments.author: Mark Hogan

comments.text:
+rauth666 Wow, I cannot believe how little you know. Seriously, have you 
not watched any documentaries? Has Cheech and chong been going around 
hurting people? If you do not know how benign pot is by now, you are 
drinking too much of the kool aid. People have different responses to 
everything. YOU MENTIONED ALCOHOL YOU IDIOT!!!!!! RESEARCH!!!!!!!!!!! The 
schizo thing is BS if you study that too. I am just saying, the numbers 
don't lie.
comments.author: ShadowEspada

comments.text: +Mark Hogan Is that comment supposed to make sense?
comments.author: rauth666

comments.text: +rauth666 Time to get shamans into society then.
comments.author: Mark Hogan

top_comment.text:
This is proof that marijuana is a plant from Satan and Hell! We need 
President Sarah Palin because she will purify this planet of weed! ﻿
top_comment.author: ecwaufisxtreme

comments.text: Sarah Palin likes weed though.
comments.author: Ryan Marshall

comments.text:
Quit looking for the devil and take a look in the mirror. There's a reason 
when the United States was established there were measures to keep religion 
out of government.
comments.author: Paden “DWE” Musk

comments.text:
I had this dream once...

Sarah Palin descended from the clouds in a golden chariot pulled by two 
mighty steeds, one named Bush, the other Cheney. Palin herself was dressed 
in the golden battle armor of the goddess, Athena and she held aloft the 
trident of Poseidon

She soon called out, her voice like a mighty gathering of trumpets "I am 
Palin, Empress of the Earth, behold my godly power!"

She then pointed the trident forward and towards the earth and a terrible 
bright beam of light shot forth from it and struck the soil. And in a 
mighty poof, the earth became a giant bran muffin.

That's when I woke up... and took a shit.

That was also the last time I ate strange colorful mushrooms before bed.
comments.author: Brian Bullock

top_comment.text:
I believe her. Edibles fuck you up. If you meet someone who says edibles 
are nothing they've never had something dank. 1 chheba chew still make you 
see the devil. (Depending on tolerance)﻿
top_comment.author: Victor Mata

comments.text:
+Rose NoHo
That's probably what happened to that woman, lol. Well, you know, it's like 
with pop tarts or ramen noodles, it says two portions per packet, but 
everyone eats the entire content and marks it as one.
comments.author: Julian Silva

comments.text:
A whole cheeba chew!? They are even marked on the outside box in 5 
sections, and they have warnings on the outside. People should know to try 
a tiny amount of an edible, and then wait for an hour to see how you react.
comments.author: Rose NoHo

comments.text: send me some.
comments.author: MSG685

top_comment.text:
From 0:39 to 2:35 sounds like a Mary J horror story. Note to self: Don't 
EVER consume marijuana or THC laced goodies. EVER!!!!!﻿
top_comment.author: CrimsonButterfly84

comments.text:
Don't consume them if you're inexperienced. An inexperienced user HAS to 
smoke it, no edibles, no vaporizing or any of that fancy stuff. Smoking is 
the best way to control your dosage and be safe, only later can you get 
into the more advanced intake methods. First time users should have the 
guidance of an experienced user to avoid any problems.
comments.author: Rič

comments.text:
Eating Cannabis provides a *much* stronger high than when smoked, it 
produces 11 Hydroxy THC which is some serious shit. Don't go for edibles 
unless you know what you're doing.
comments.author: tbizzleONE

comments.text: +Z200a thanks
comments.author: MSG685

comments.text:
+jared westphal That is good to know, but no thanks. I don't do 
recreational narcotics. It's not my thing. I might have an alcoholic 
beverage once or twice a year.
comments.author: CrimsonButterfly84

comments.text: +MSG685  *passes the blunt to the left hand side* ;-)
comments.author: CrimsonButterfly84

comments.text:
From what I remember, she ate some....didn't feel anything so ate some 
more....then went into a hallucinatory episode.  Sadly I don't think there 
is enough weed on earth to get me THAT high anymore...ahh the good ol' 
days....

comments.text:
I read somewhere (wasn't able to find it again, unfortunately) that she ate

into, you'll be fine. More education and better labeling is the key.

comments.text: the story mentioned it was only a dosage issue.
